title: 112_s1544
content: The "Small Company Capital Formation Act of 2011" allows for the exemption of certain securities. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to add additional exemptions for small issues, allowing for the offering and sale of securities up to $50,000,000 publicly. The amended Securities Act of 1933 allows for the public offering and sale of securities, with certain conditions such as not being restricted securities, application of civil liability provisions, pre-offering solicitation, and annual filing of audited financial statements. The Securities Act of 1933 requires the annual filing of audited financial statements with the Commission and may include additional terms and conditions determined necessary for investor protection. The Securities Act of 1933 requires annual filing of audited financial statements with the Commission and may include additional terms for investor protection. Exemption provisions under the Act include corporate governance principles, use of investor funds, and disqualification provisions similar to those in the Dodd-Frank Act. Only specific types of securities may be exempted under the regulations. The Securities Act of 1933 requires annual filing of audited financial statements with the Commission and may include additional terms for investor protection. Exemption provisions under the Act include corporate governance principles, use of investor funds, and disqualification provisions similar to those in the Dodd-Frank Act. Specific types of securities, such as equity securities, debt securities, and debt securities convertible to equity interests, may be exempted under regulations. The Commission may require periodic disclosures from issuers of exempted securities regarding their business operations, financial condition, corporate governance principles, and use of investor funds. The Small Company Capital Formation Act of 2011 allows for the adjustment of offering amount limitations every 2 years by the Commission. If the Commission decides not to increase the amount, it must report to specific committees. Additionally, certain securities are treated as Covered Securities for NSMIA purposes under the Securities Act of 1933. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include rules and regulations adopted pursuant to section 3(b)(2) for securities offered or sold on a national securities exchange or to a qualified purchaser. Section 4(5) is also amended to reference section 3(b)(1). The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the impact of State Blue Sky laws on Regulation A offerings and report findings to relevant committees.
